channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: GSoC 2012
item.description: Europe is still freezing but Google and Mark Keating are already thinking about the summer and the code. The Perl Foundation wants to participate again which means you need to give ideas and volunteer as mentor.

item.title: DWIM Perl 5.14 for Windows (v7) released
item.description: This is the second DWIM release in a week. The first one was using Perl 5.12 but this one already uses the latest version of Perl and includes more than 400 modules from CPAN.

item.title: The unexpected case of -Mblib
item.description: I think this is not the first time we catch Reini Urban eliminating bloat from our perl scripts.

item.title: Module review updates
item.description: Neil Bowers is linking to the updated version of his report about 'defining constants'. I really love the comparisons Neil is doing. I am looking forward to the day when his reports will be somehow available on the search interfaces of CPAN. E.g. when a module that he lists is being displayed there could be a link to his article.

item.title: Perl Data Language gets auto-parallelisation
item.description: The announcement about the new version of PDL made it into The H.

item.title: Dancer updates
item.description: Sawyer X is, understandably, very enthusiastic about the community around the Dancer project but he also lists a number of changes that went into Dancer in the last 2 weeks. If you'd like to have the warm feeling of being in an open source community, this is for you.

item.title: The Values and Costs of Automation
item.description: chromatic make a good point about automating parts of packaging CPAN modules or anything really.

item.title: Plat-forms 2012 : Perl on Amazon Web Services ?
item.description: Laurent Dami (dami) started to prepare for the next Plat-forms competition that will take place in April in Berlin but he is worried the lack of Perl on AWS will make it hard for the Perl team. What do you think?

item.title: Annotations, Attributes, Traits
item.description: Peter Shangov describes how other languages (Java, C#, Python handle meta-data on objects and then offers some suggestion how he would like to write meta-data declarations.

item.title: Unicode and Passwords
item.description: Do you allow strange characters in the username field? What about the password field? Don't have people enough problem tying with Caps-lock on by mistake? Check some of the issues with Unicode and passwords as Curtis (Ovid) Poe thinks about them.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - January 2012 - Bringing It All Back Home
item.description: CPAN Testers is unique in its size and all that depends on a very small number of people. Mostly on Barbie, who wrote this monthly report.

item.title: Easy and Attractive Graphs with Chart::Clicker
item.description: chromatic shows a small example on the awesomeness of Chart::Clicker. I also like the module but I think last time I checked, I could not install it on Windows. I'll have to check that again and try to figure out what might be the problem.

item.title: DistZilla from one newb to another
item.description: Mark Allen shared his slides from the talk he gave at Houston.pm. Very nice slides. I am sorry we don't have the actual presentation.

item.title: t2: Sums of cubes
item.description: Moritz Lenz writes: The second task from the Perl 6 Coding Contest 2011 needs data structures not available in core Perl 6 to be solved efficiently.

item.title: Bounded serialization, better regexes and better errors
item.description: by Jonathan Worthington

item.title: Mini-Challenge: Write Your Prisoner's Dilemma Strategy
item.description: Moritz Lenz invites us to another Perl 6 challenge. This time he describes the well known dilemma, offers some strategies and the check-sum of his solution. It's like putting the solution in an envelop in a trusted third party. Very nice idea.

item.title: 2012Q1 TPF Grant Proposal: Cooking Perl with Chef
item.description: David Golden submitted a grant proposal. I think it would be important to get comments from more people.

item.title: Hacker Newsletter
item.description: If you are like me, who would like to read the Hacker News of Ycombinator but does not have the time to follow it, the newsletter of Kale Davis might help you keep an eye on the most important postings.

item.title: Scripting for DB2 LUW - Why Perl?
item.description: Ember Crooks tells her story, why she learned Perl and how Perl was chosen in the DB2 team in IBM.

item.title: Presentation training from Damian Conway
item.description: Ian Norton mentioned the training Damian will give on 16 April 2012 in London.

item.title: Announcing my first Perl e-book
item.description: I have been planning to publish my Perl training materials along with the newly written Perl set of articles. This is the first one with the Beginner Perl Maven material.

item.title: $_ the default variable of Perl
item.description: IMHO for beginners it's quite hard to find explanation on what are the special variables of Perl. Especially $_ is confusing people and search engines. I hope my little contribution helps.

item.title: Automatic string to number conversion or casting in Perl
item.description: People coming from other programming languages often have trouble with the automatic string to number conversion in Perl. The comments also mention a couple of strange cases.

item.title: Perl Workshop in Israel
item.description: February 28, 2012, Ramat Gan, Israel

item.title: German Perl workshop
item.description: March 5-7, 2012, Erlangen, Germany

item.title: DC-Baltimore Perl workshop
item.description: April 14, 2012, Catonsville, MD, USA
